title: Riot Dev blog: Mount Targon

embed.description: Journey to Mount Targon as Jellbug and Whren explore Runeterra's highest peak and discuss the lives of those in Mount Targon's shadow.

body: Here it is. I'm more confused.

replies.body: I'm curious as to how long a successful climb to the pinnacle of mount Targon would take.

How fast can you throw a ball?
{{sticker:sg-lulu}} 

Jokes aside, while the mountain seems pretty god damn high, it can't take too long. A few days at max probably.
I mean, Taric climbed it in his comic without any supplies.

It took Atreus and Pylas months, of course this was likely due to the size of their group, the Mountain needed to kill them off to find who was worthy. So it varies from person to person, in a real life setting the difference in time taken would probably be attributed to the paths taken by different climbers, whereas in the lore its written to be the Aspects manipulating the mountain paths to test their hosts.

Yup, this! The mountain magically warps itself, shifting and contracting based on the unique test it creates for each climber. So some climbers might get to the top in a day (e.g. Diana), while others take months.
Shout out to whoever came up with the dead bodies being warped into the stone, that is brutal and so awesome.

That was me! It was an idea that came about after seeing pictures of volcanic lava that looked really corpse-like. And after we thought that it would be cool to have a spiritual/emotional testing thing instead of just rock and snow, it seemed a great way to make a climber lose their mind on the way up.
I’m curious, what exactly was Leona being tested for? She made it to the top in 1 night, and didn’t have any morals challenged until after the space parasite got in her.

Don’t forget, she was tested much earlier when she first saw the golden-skinned child-beast, at which point she went against her Rakkor upbringing and helped him rahee than killed him. That was probably the only test that Targonian had for her, whether she would try to kill him or show compassion for him despite his monstrous appearance.
If that was the test, I don't think the Aspects understand how time functions.  Since Leona the (I'm gonna randomly say 10) years later was a much harsher and more bloodthirsty person.

They’re ancient, and we don’t know how time works in the true Targon. They probably know how people change, considering how long they’ve been doing this symbiotic relationship/empowering of theirs. 

Sometimes people do change like that, but they still remember where they came from and emotions they felt prior. Leona was harsher because she was in command of the Solari’s elite defensive group. You have to be harsh there when facing all sorts of opposition. And I wouldn’t call her bloodthirsty. Zealous, indoctrinated, but not bloodthirsty. She felt a threat from Diana, and after the elders were killed, she rightly pursued her. If you’re entire leadership was slaughtered, would you not seek out the one who killed them to bring them to justice?

As for the Sun, he probably figured that the compassion was still a part of her, and perhaps on seeing him she remembered. It’s not the first 180 upon meeting a deity we’ve seen like this either, albeit not necessarily in the lore. In our own history, there are many people who did such a thing, the most prominent in my mind is Paul from Biblical times, who went from wanted to kill Christians to becoming one himself after an encounter with the God of the Bible.
Here’s the rub, Sun isn’t forgiving and compassionate. On the contrary the one interaction we know for certain was the Sun’s opinion is it delighting at the thought of setting people on fire.

That one interaction is the quote on the summary, yes?

> "If you would shine like a sun, first you must burn like one."

Why does it make you think the sun delights in setting people on fire? That’s very much taking those words at face value. There is a metaphoric meaning for burning as well: purification, as iron and silver are purified in flames. It’s a burning away of impurity to make something stronger and more beautiful, but it doesn’t mean literally setting people on fire. Usually the fire is passing through suffering or a trial to put you in a place of weakness, and if you come out on the other side, you become stronger for it. That is how I interpret that saying because, clearly, Leona does not get set on fire.
Color text in Leona’s story. Leona fights some bandits and the Sun is freaking jubilant at the thought of burning them all.

This might not be very useful info, but -- fun fact! We did research on how long it takes people to climb mountains and consulted a mountain-climber who had scaled Everest multiple times (eight? I think). Our reference informed us that if one didn't stop to camp, the journey itself in raw physical distance would only be a couple days. However, most of the time spent is spent on acclimatizing, setting up camp, going up to higher elevations and then back down again once the body has gotten used to it, and then finally making the push to the top and then quickly coming down again before the lack of oxygen kills the climber. In total, that makes climbing attempts stretch out to many, many weeks just to overcome the physical limitations of the human body.

Given that Targon is a fair bit bigger than Everest, we thought about the absolute amount of time it would take if the mountain didn't do its stretchy mind-bendy thing, and it would be about three weeks to a month (if we assume the presence of magic and the fact that we have characters in our world that are no mere humans).

Neat info about Mount Targon, but almost nothing about Targonians themselves -.-

I would've liked to see more substantial information too, but I think it's cool that we know a little bit more about Targon now -- particularly that there's a portal at the top of the peak (whereas before it was a bit ambiguous IIRC), and how exactly that's happening. The Lunari and Solari art is absolutely awesome too, you really get a feel for the majesty of Leona's group and the nocturnal nature of the Lunari. I would've liked to see more of the Rakkor though, none of the people shown in their artwork looked anything like warriors or Pantheon.

It'd be cool to get these videos and sets of artwork every time we get a new champion or VGU for each region, discovering something each time.

The Rakkor image there is mainly to showcase the regular folk who live on the mountain — those who gather food, protect flocks, make the place liveable, and so on. Visually, we had to come up with a clothing aesthetic that was both ancient and yet not overly primitive. We wanted to expand on the idea of people living there looking like Spartans from 300, so at least within the images published, you’d see more of the martial warrior type (and bare skin) within the Solari, where their faith and religion encourage them to train to withstand the cold.

The only actual new piece of lore is there are other Lunari in hiding and Zoe didn’t ascend the mountain. Which I assume was also reviewed in her lore.

I think it’s important, especially for future readers or lore enthusiasts. They’d never find out about the video otherwise, unless they went digging through Youtube or came across it by chance.

Or you can go to the Nexus where all the Dev diaries / blogs are archived. Sure over time one would have to do some "digging" there but nothing too significant, since Nexus has lore related categories to shorten the searching!

But sure, implying that would be difficult is one way to perceive things.
Or you could just put it on Universe and make it easy.
